covered: POST > Valid Payload: Multiple happy-path scenarios verify 201 Created, JSON Account body, and Location header (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC16).
POST > Invalid Payload: Malformed JSON, missing required fields, and empty payload return 400 with error messaging (TC05, TC06, TC12).
Headers > Required/Optional: Required X-Killbill-CreatedBy validated; optional X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment exercised (TC02, TC03, TC04, TC08).
Error Handling > Dependency/Infrastructure: Database unavailable returns 503; network timeout returns 504 (TC10, TC14).
POST > Large Payloads: Boundary test with maximum allowed sizes results in successful creation (TC11).
Robustness > Unexpected Inputs: Extra unsupported fields in body are handled; unexpected headers tolerated (TC07, TC17).
Regression/Performance/Integration: Concurrency performance (TC18), regression fix check (TC19), and post-create retrieval via Location (TC20).
gaps: POST > Validation specifics: No tests for field-level validation rules (e.g., email format, numeric ranges, enum constraints, locale/currency codes).
POST > Content negotiation/headers: No test for Content-Type=application/json requirement (e.g., missing/incorrect Content-Type), or response Content-Type=application/json per Produces.
POST > Duplicate Submission: Behavior not asserted deterministically; TC13 allows 201 or 409 without clear expectation.
POST > Server Error Handling: No scenario for generic 500 Internal Server Error per guideline (e.g., unhandled exception), only 503/504 covered.

Response headers completeness: No assertions for Location being absolute/valid URI format, nor for other standard headers (e.g., Date, Content-Length) if required; no ETag/versioning expectations if applicable.
Security/input hardening: XSS/SQL injection scenario (TC15) is vague; no explicit expected status/normalization outcome and no coverage for header injection or CRLF in headers.
Idempotency/retry semantics: No coverage for safe retry behavior (e.g., duplicate POST on network retry) if required by API contract.
JSON schema enforcement breadth: No tests for type mismatches inside Account fields (strings vs numbers), array lengths, nested object constraints, or unknown nested properties.
recommendations: Add field-level validation scenarios (e.g., invalid email format, out-of-range numeric fields, invalid country/locale/currency codes) expecting 400 with precise error messages.
Add Content-Type handling tests: missing Content-Type, incorrect media type, charset variations; assert response Content-Type=application/json on success and error paths.
Clarify and codify duplicate behavior: split TC13 into two explicit scenarios based on product policy (expect 201 with same resource or 409 Conflict with error body).
Include a 500 Internal Server Error simulation (e.g., forced unhandled exception) and verify error body contract.
Tighten TC15: specify expected outcome (e.g., 400 with validation error and safely-escaped echo, or 201 with sanitized stored values) and assert no script execution/SQL side effects.
Validate Location header format (absolute URL, correct path with new account ID/UUID) and ensure it is present only on 201; also assert response Produces header application/json.
Expand schema/type tests: wrong data types for Account fields, nested objects, arrays, and unknown nested properties; ensure clear error paths.
If applicable to API standards, add idempotency/retry tests (e.g., same payload re-sent after timeout) to ensure no unintended duplicates.
